# A Useful lemmas 

We are first interested in discrete random variables $Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}$ following a two-point distribution with values in $\{-1,1\}$. If $\mathbb{P}\left(Y_{1}=1\right)=p$, we note $Y \sim \mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}(p)$. In the case where $p=1 / 2$, this distribution is simply the Rademacher distribution, in which case $\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}\right]=0$ and $\operatorname{Var}\left(Y_{1}\right)=1$. The aim of the following lemma is to decompose a set of correlated Rademacher variables in independent two-point variables. The correlation structure allowed by the lemma encompasses independent variables, like in Sections 2.2.1 and 2.2.2, as well as time series with an exponentially decaying correlation, like in Sections 2.2.3 and 2.2.4.

Lemma 1. Let $Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}$ be $n$ variables in $\mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}(1 / 2)$ with correlation $\operatorname{corr}\left(Y_{i}, Y_{j}\right)=\rho_{i, j}$, such that $\rho_{k, i}=\rho_{k, j} \rho_{j, i}$ for $i \leq j \leq k$. Let's introduce $n-1$ variables $Z_{i} \sim \mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}\left(\left(1+\rho_{i, i-1}\right) / 2\right)$, for $i \in \llbracket 2, n \rrbracket$, such that the $n$ variables $Y_{1}, Z_{2}, \ldots, Z_{n}$ are mutually independent. Then, the vectors $\left(Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}\right)^{T}$ and $\left(Y_{1}, Y_{1} Z_{2}, \ldots, Y_{1} \prod_{j=2}^{n} Z_{j}\right)^{T}$ have the same distribution.

Before proving Lemma 1, it is worth noting that the variable $Z_{i}$ has the following moments: $\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{i}^{2 k+1}\right]=\rho_{i, i-1}$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[Z_{i}^{2 k}\right]=1$, for $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.

Proof. Let $Y_{i}^{\prime}=Y_{1} \prod_{j=2}^{i} Z_{j}$. We have $Y_{i} \sim \mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}(1 / 2)$ and $Y_{i}^{\prime} \sim \mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}(p)$, with $p$ to be determined. The expected value of a variable in $\mathcal{D}_{\{-1,1\}}(p)$ is $2 p-1$. By independence, we have $\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1} \prod_{j=2}^{i} Z_{j}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}\right] \prod_{j=2}^{i} \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{j}\right]=0$, so that $p=1 / 2$. Therefore, $Y_{i}$ and $Y_{i}^{\prime}$ have the same marginal distribution. We now focus on the dependence structure. Let $i \leq j$. Then, due to the particular moments of the distribution, the correlation between $Y_{i}^{\prime}$ and $Y_{j}^{\prime}$ is equal to $\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i}^{\prime} Y_{j}^{\prime}\right]$, which, using the independence, is equal to $\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}^{2} \prod_{k=2}^{i} Z_{k}^{2} \prod_{k=i+1}^{j} Z_{k}\right]=\prod_{k=i+1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{k}\right]=$ $\prod_{k=i+1}^{j} \rho_{k, k-1}$. This last product is equal to $\rho_{j, i}$ by assumption, which is precisely the correlation between $Y_{i}$ and $Y_{j}$.

In the next lemma, we will use the decomposition of the $n$ variables $Y_{1}, \ldots, Y_{n}$ in products of $n$ independent variables. This lemma provides a cokurtosis of two random variables mixing correlated Gaussian variables and correlated two-point variables. It will be useful for determining the variance of the empirical variance of price log-returns in the four specifications studied in this paper.
Lemma 2. Let $G_{a}, G_{b} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \sigma_{G}^{2}\right)$ of correlation $\rho_{G}, Y_{1}, Y_{2}, Y_{3}$ and $Y_{4}$ be four Rademacher variables independent of $G_{a}$ and $G_{b}$, with $\operatorname{corr}\left(Y_{i}, Y_{j}\right)=\rho_{i, j}$, such that $\rho_{k, i}=\rho_{k, j} \rho_{j, i}$ for $i \leq j \leq k$. We define

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\mathcal{K}^{-}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G_{a}+Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(G_{b}+Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)^{2}\right] \\
\mathcal{K}^{+}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(G_{a}+Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(G_{b}+Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)^{2}\right]
\end{array}\right.
$$

Then, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{-}= & \left(1+2 \rho_{G}^{2}\right) \sigma_{G}^{4}+2 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(2-\rho_{4,3}-\rho_{2,1}\right) \\
& +4\left(1-\rho_{2,1}\right)\left(1-\rho_{4,3}\right)+4 \rho_{G} \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(\rho_{3,1}-\rho_{4,1}-\rho_{3,2}+\rho_{4,2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{+}= & \left(1+2 \rho_{G}^{2}\right) \sigma_{G}^{4}+2 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(2-\rho_{4,2}-\rho_{3,1}\right) \\
& +4\left(1-\rho_{4,2}-\rho_{3,1}+\rho_{4,3} \rho_{2,1}\right)+4 \rho_{G} \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(\rho_{4,3}-\rho_{3,2}-\rho_{4,1}+\rho_{2,1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof. Using the Cholesky decomposition, we write $G_{b}=\rho_{G} G_{a}+\sqrt{1-\rho_{G}^{2}} G_{b, a}$, where $G_{b, a} \sim$ $\mathcal{N}\left(0, \sigma_{G}^{2}\right)$ is independent of $G_{a}$. As a consequence,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2} G_{b}^{2}\right] & =\rho_{G}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{4}\right]+2 \rho_{G} \sqrt{1-\rho_{G}^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{3}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[G_{b, a}\right]+\left(1-\rho_{G}^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[G_{b, a}^{2}\right] \\
& =\left(1+2 \rho_{G}^{2}\right) \sigma_{G}^{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used the Gaussian assumption, which leads to a kurtosis of 3 . We also have, for $j \geq i$, using the decomposition in a product of independent variables, as in Lemma 1, and the assumption on the product of correlations,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{i}-Y_{j}\right)^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i}^{2}\left(1-\prod_{k=i+1}^{j} Z_{k}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{i}^{2}\right]\left(1-2 \prod_{k=i+1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{k}\right]+\prod_{k=i+1}^{j} \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{k}^{2}\right]\right) \\
& =2-2 \prod_{k=i+1}^{j} \rho_{k, k-1} \\
& =2\left(1-\rho_{j, i}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

as well as, using a standard expansion of the product,

$$
\left\{\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)\left(Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)\right] & =\rho_{3,1}-\rho_{4,1}-\rho_{3,2}+\rho_{4,2} \\
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)\left(Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)\right] & =\rho_{4,3}-\rho_{3,2}-\rho_{4,1}+\rho_{2,1}
\end{aligned}\right.
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}^{4}\left(1-Z_{2}\right)^{2}\left(1-Z_{4}\right)^{2} Z_{3}^{2} Z_{2}^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}^{4}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-Z_{2}\right)^{2} Z_{2}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-Z_{4}\right)^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[Z_{3}^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-Z_{2}\right)^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-Z_{4}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =4\left(1-\rho_{2,1}\right)\left(1-\rho_{4,3}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and, similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[Y_{1}^{4}\left(Z_{3} Z_{2}-1\right)^{2}\left(Z_{4} Z_{3}-1\right)^{2} Z_{2}^{2}\right] \\
& =4 \mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-Z_{3} Z_{2}\right)\left(1-Z_{4} Z_{3}\right)\right] \\
& =4 \mathbb{E}\left[1-Z_{4} Z_{3}-Z_{3} Z_{2}+Z_{4} Z_{3}^{2} Z_{2}\right] \\
& =4\left(1-\rho_{4,3} \rho_{3,2}-\rho_{3,2} \rho_{2,1}+\rho_{4,3} \rho_{2,1}\right) \\
& =4\left(1-\rho_{4,2}-\rho_{3,1}+\rho_{4,3} \rho_{2,1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using all these preliminary results, the zero mean and the independence between the Gaussian and the two-point variables, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{-}= & \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2} G_{b}^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[G_{b}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)^{2}\right]+4 \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a} G_{b}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{2}-Y_{1}\right)\left(Y_{4}-Y_{3}\right)\right] \\
= & (1+2 \rho_{G}^{2}) \sigma_{G}^{4}+2 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(2-\rho_{4,3}-\rho_{2,1}\right) \\
& +4\left(1-\rho_{2,1}\right)\left(1-\rho_{4,3}\right)+4 \rho_{G} \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(\rho_{3,1}-\rho_{4,1}-\rho_{3,2}+\rho_{4,2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{+}= & \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2} G_{b}^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[G_{a}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[G_{b}^{2}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& +\mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)^{2}\left(Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)^{2}\right]+4 \mathbb{E}\left[G_{a} G_{b}\right] \mathbb{E}\left[\left(Y_{3}-Y_{1}\right)\left(Y_{4}-Y_{2}\right)\right] \\
= & (1+2 \rho_{G}^{2}) \sigma_{G}^{4}+2 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(2-\rho_{4,2}-\rho_{3,1}\right) \\
& +4\left(1-\rho_{4,2}-\rho_{3,1}+\rho_{4,3} \rho_{2,1}\right)+4 \rho_{G} \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(\rho_{4,3}-\rho_{3,2}-\rho_{4,1}+\rho_{2,1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

# B. 2 Proof of Proposition 2 

Proof. The result on the first moment is a straightforward consequence of the linearity of the expectation and of equation (3).

For $v=3$, using the stationarity of the increments, the second moment is

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{k_{3}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k_{3}(n, L)-1}\left\{K(L \tau, L \tau)+2 \sum_{j=i+1}^{k_{3}(n, L)-1} K(L \tau,(i-j+(i-j+1) L) \tau)\right\}
$$

All the terms in each sum are equal, so that we just have to count the number of terms in each:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)^{2}\right] & =\frac{k_{3}(n, L) K(L \tau, L \tau)+k_{3}(n, L)\left(k_{3}(n, L)-1\right) K(L \tau, 0)}{k_{3}(n, L)^{2}} \\
& =V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{2 \sigma^{4} L^{2} \tau^{2}+2 \sigma^{2} L \tau S^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}}{k_{3}(n, L)}
\end{aligned}
$$

which, by subtracting $V(L \tau)^{2}$, leads to the variance.
For $v=2$, we have the same kind of double sum as in equation (21), except that $k_{3}(n, L)$ is to be replaced by $k_{2}(n, L)$ :

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{2}(n, L)^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{k_{2}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k_{2}(n, L)-1}\left\{K(L \tau, L \tau)+2 \sum_{j=i+1}^{k_{2}(n, L)-1} K(L \tau,(i-j+1) L \tau)\right\}
$$

with the terms $K(L \tau,(i-j+1) L \tau)$ all equal to $K(L \tau, 0)$. We thus get a very similar result as in the case $v=3$ :

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\widehat{V}_{2}(n, L)\right]=\frac{2 \sigma^{4} L^{2} \tau^{2}+2 \sigma^{2} L \tau S^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}}{k_{2}(n, L)}
$$

For $v=1$, the same kind of decomposition as in equation (21) leads to $k_{1}(n, L)^{2}$ terms, $k_{1}(n, L)$ of which corresponding to synchronized increments and thus to $K(L \tau, L \tau), 2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-l\right)$ terms corresponding to overlapping increments with a duration of overlap being equal to $(L-l) \tau$, all the other terms corresponding to non-overlapping increments and thus to $K(L \tau, 0)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)^{2}\right]= & \frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\left(k_{1}(n, L) K(L \tau, L \tau)+\sum_{l=1}^{L-1} 2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-l\right) K(L \tau,(L-l) \tau)\right. \\
& \left.+\left(k_{1}(n, L)^{2}-k_{1}(n, L)-\sum_{l=1}^{L-1} 2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-l\right)\right) K(L \tau, 0)\right) \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\left(k_{1}(n, L)\left(2 \sigma^{4} L^{2} \tau^{2}+2 \sigma^{2} L \tau S^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\right)\right. \\
& \left.+4 \sigma^{4} \sum_{m=1}^{L-1}\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L+m\right) m^{2} \tau^{2}\right) \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)}\left(2 \sigma^{4} L^{2} \tau^{2}+2 \sigma^{2} L \tau S^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}+4 \sigma^{4} \tau^{2} \sum_{m=1}^{L-1} m^{2}\right) \\
& +\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\right) \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)}\left(\frac{2}{3} \sigma^{4} L\left(1+2 L^{2}\right) \tau^{2}+2 \sigma^{2} L \tau S^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting that $k_{1}(n, L)=n-L$, we get the expected result.

## B. 3 Proof of Theorem 1

Proof. The absence of bias is a direct consequence of Proposition 2 and equation (4).

The increments of $p$ in $\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)$ being independent of each other, $\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)$ converges almost surely toward $V(L \tau)$, by the strong law of large numbers. We obtain a similar result for $\widehat{V}_{3}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)$ toward $V\left(L^{\prime} \tau\right)$. The continuous mapping theorem applied with $g:(x, y) \mapsto 2\left(L^{\prime} x-L y\right) /\left(L^{\prime}-L\right)$ thus leads to the almost sure convergence of $\widehat{S_{1,3}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}\right)$ toward $2\left(L^{\prime} V(L \tau)-L V\left(L^{\prime} \tau\right)\right) /\left(L^{\prime}-L\right)$, which is equal to $S^{2}$, according to equation (4).
Regarding the convergence of $\widehat{S_{1, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}\right)$ for $v \in\{1,2\}$, we first note, using Proposition 2, that $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$ converges in probability toward $V(L \tau)$ because its asymptotic quadratic risk is zero. Then, using also the continuous mapping theorem, one concludes that $\widehat{S_{1, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}\right)$ converges in probability toward $S^{2}$.
For the convergence in distribution, we first note that $\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)$ (respectively $\widehat{V}_{2}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)$ ) is a sum of $L$-dependent (resp. 1-dependent, 0 -dependent) identically distributed variables. Therefore, following the formalism of [18, Theorem 27.4] whatever $v \in\{1,2,3\}, \widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$ is trivially a sum of an $\alpha$-mixing sequence, with $\alpha_{n}=0$ for $n$ sufficiently large, so that the central limit theorem applies:

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)-V(L \tau)\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \zeta_{v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}^{2}(L)\right)
$$

Its multivariate version, applied to the vector $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)\right)^{T}$, also holds, because this vector is a sum of vectors which are also dependent at a finite range only and thus $\alpha$-mixing (the case $v=3$ and $L^{\prime}=m(L+1)-1$, presented in the last part of the proof, shows how the sum of vectors can be decomposed in such a way as to get rid of the dependence):

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\left(\begin{array}{c}
\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L) \\
\widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)
\end{array}\right)-\left(\begin{array}{c}
V(L \tau) \\
V\left(L^{\prime} \tau\right)
\end{array}\right)\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}_{2}(0, \Sigma)
$$

where $\mathcal{N}_{2}$ is the bivariate Gaussian distribution and

$$
\Sigma=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\zeta_{v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}^{2}(L) & \sqrt{\zeta_{v}(L) \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right)} \sigma_{1, v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) r_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right) \\
\sqrt{\zeta_{v}(L) \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right)} \sigma_{1, v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) r_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right) & \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) \sigma_{1, v}^{2}\left(L^{\prime}\right)
\end{array}\right)
$$

Then, we want to apply the delta method with the function $g$. The gradient of $g$ is

$$
\nabla g(x, y)=\frac{2}{L^{\prime}-L}\binom{L^{\prime}}{-L}
$$

We also have $g\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)\right)=\widehat{S_{1, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}\right)$ and, after equation (4), $g\left(V(L \tau), V\left(L^{\prime} \tau\right)\right)=$ $S^{2}$. Therefore,

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{S_{1, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}\right)-S^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \gamma_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right)\right)
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right) & =\frac{4}{\left(L^{\prime}-L\right)^{2}}\binom{L^{\prime}}{-L}^{T} \Sigma\binom{L^{\prime}}{-L} \\
& =\frac{4}{\left(L^{\prime}-L\right)^{2}}\left(L^{\prime 2} \zeta_{v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}^{2}(L)+L^{2} \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) \sigma_{1, v}^{2}\left(L^{\prime}\right)-2 L L^{\prime} \sqrt{\zeta_{v}(L) \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right)} \sigma_{1, v}(L) \sigma_{1, v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) r_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

This proves equation (7).
We now focus on the case $v=3, L^{\prime}=m(L+1)-1$. We start by applying the central limit theorem to the vector

$$
\binom{\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)}{\widehat{V}_{3}(n, m(L+1)-1)}=\frac{M}{n} \sum_{i=0}^{(n / M)-1}\binom{\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=0}^{m-1}\left(p_{(j+i M+(j+1) L) \tau}-p_{(j+i M+j L) \tau}\right)^{2}}{\left(p_{(i+(i+1)(M-1)) \tau}-p_{(i+i(M-1)) \tau}\right)^{2}}
$$

in which, for the convenience of the notation and without any consequence on the result of the central limit theorem, we assume that $n$ is a multiple of $M$, where we note $M=m(L+1)$ the number of time steps between two starts of consecutive low-frequency increments in $\widetilde{V}_{3}(n, m(L+1)-1)$. In the above vector, we have split the $n /(L+1)$ disjoint increments appearing in $\widetilde{V}_{3}(n, L)$ in $n / M$ groups of $m$ consecutive disjoint increments, so that each group overlaps with a single increment appearing in $\widetilde{V}_{3}(n, m(L+1)-1)$. More precisely, noting $A_{i, j}=p_{(j+i M+(j+1) L) \tau}-p_{(j+i M+j L) \tau}$ and $B_{i, j}=p_{(j+1+i M+(j+1) L) \tau}-p_{(j+i M+(j+1) L) \tau}$, a low-frequency increment is the sum of the successive non-overlapping increments, with one bound in common, $A_{i, 0}, B_{i, 0}, A_{i, 1}, B_{i, 1}, \ldots, B_{i, m-2}, A_{i, m-1}$. We are thus interested in the vector

$$
\mathbf{Y}_{i}=\left(\begin{array}{c}
\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=0}^{m-1} A_{i, j}^{2} \\
\left(\sum_{j=0}^{m-1} A_{i, j}+\sum_{j=0}^{m-2} B_{i, j}\right)^{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

for $i \in \llbracket 0,(n / M)-1 \rrbracket$. The vector defined in equation (25) is the sum of all the $\mathbf{Y}_{i}$, which are all independent to each other and identically distributed. We note $\Sigma^{Y}$ the covariance matrix of a vector $\mathbf{Y}_{i}$. We are looking for an expression of the covariance $\Sigma_{12}^{Y}$ between the two components of $\mathbf{Y}_{i}$ :

$$
\Sigma_{12}^{Y}=\Sigma_{21}^{Y}=\operatorname{Cov}\left(\frac{1}{m} \sum_{j=0}^{m-1} A_{i, j^{\prime}}^{2}\left(\sum_{j^{\prime}=0}^{m-1} A_{i, j^{\prime}}+\sum_{j^{\prime}=0}^{m-2} B_{i, j^{\prime}}\right)^{2}\right)
$$

Since $A_{i, j}$ is independent from $A_{i, j^{\prime}}$ for $j^{\prime} \neq j$ and from $B_{i, j^{\prime}}$ for $j^{\prime} \notin\{j-1, j\}$, since $\mathbb{E}\left(A_{i, j}\right)=$ $\mathbb{E}\left(B_{i, j}\right)=0$, and since the $A_{i, j}$ (respectively the $B_{i, j}$ ) are identically distributed, the covariance can be simplified to the following expression, for any $i$ and any $j$ such that the variables are defined,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{12}^{Y}= & \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j}^{2}\right)+\frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j}^{2}\right)+\frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1}^{2}\right) \\
& +2 \frac{m-2}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1} B_{i, j}\right)+2 \frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j} B_{i, j}\right)+2 \frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j} B_{i, j-1}\right) \\
& +2 \frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j} A_{i, j+1}\right)+2 \frac{m-1}{m} \operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1} A_{i, j-1}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j}^{2}\right)=K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}
$$

whose expression is provided in Proposition 1,

$$
\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j}^{2}\right)=\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1}^{2}\right)=\operatorname{Cov}\left(\eta^{2}, \eta^{2}\right)=0
$$

noting that the square of the random variable $\eta$., which has a value in $\{-S / 2, S / 2\}$, is a constant (equal to $\left.S^{2} / 4\right)$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1} B_{i, j}\right) & =\operatorname{Cov}\left(\eta^{2}+\eta_{-L \tau}^{2}-2 \eta \eta_{.+L \tau},-\eta \eta_{.+L \tau}\right) \\
& =2 \operatorname{Var}\left(\eta \eta_{.+L \tau}\right) \\
& =2 \mathbb{E}\left(\eta^{2}\right)^{2}-2 \mathbb{E}\left(\eta_{.}\right)^{4}=\frac{S^{4}}{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

because $\mathbb{E}\left(\eta_{.}\right)=0$ and $\eta$. and $\eta_{.+L \tau}$ are independent and identically distributed,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j} A_{i, j+1}\right) & =\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, B_{i, j-1} A_{i, j-1}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Cov}\left(\eta_{.}^{2}+\eta_{.+L \tau}^{2}-2 \eta \eta_{.+L \tau},\left(-\eta_{.+L \tau}+\eta_{.+(L+1) \tau}\right) \eta_{.+(L+1) \tau}\right)=0
\end{aligned}
$$

for similar reasons, and, noting $A_{i, j}^{\star}=p_{(j+i M+(j+1) L) \tau}^{\star}-p_{(j+i M+j L) \tau}^{\star}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j} B_{i, j}\right) & =\operatorname{Cov}\left(A_{i, j}^{2}, A_{i, j} B_{i, j-1}\right) \\
& =\operatorname{Cov}\left(\left(A_{i, j}^{\star}-\eta_{.}+\eta_{.+L \tau}\right)^{2},-\left(A_{i, j}^{\star}-\eta_{.}+\eta_{.+L \tau}\right) \eta_{.+L \tau}\right) \\
& =-2 \operatorname{Var}\left(A_{i, j}^{\star} \eta_{.+L \tau}\right)-2 \operatorname{Var}\left(\eta \eta_{.+L \tau}\right) \\
& =-2 \mathbb{E}\left(\left(A_{i, j}^{\star}\right)^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}\left(\eta_{.+L \tau}^{2}\right)-2 \mathbb{E}\left(\eta^{2}\right) \mathbb{E}\left(\eta_{.+L \tau}^{2}\right) \\
& =-\sigma^{2} L \tau \frac{S^{2}}{2}-\frac{S^{4}}{8}=-\frac{S^{2}}{2} V(L \tau)+\frac{S^{4}}{8}
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, with all these intermediary calculations, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Sigma_{12}^{Y} & =K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{m-2}{m} \frac{S^{4}}{4}+4 \frac{m-1}{m}\left(-\frac{S^{2}}{2} V(L \tau)+\frac{S^{4}}{8}\right) \\
& =K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}-2 \frac{m-1}{m} S^{2} V(L \tau)+\frac{3 m-4}{m} \frac{S^{4}}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Proposition 2, we also find that the diagonal terms of $\Sigma^{Y}$ are

$$
\Sigma_{11}^{Y}=\frac{1}{m}\left(K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}\right)
$$

and

$$
\Sigma_{22}^{Y}=K((M-1) \tau,(M-1) \tau)-V((M-1) \tau)^{2}
$$

We can then apply the multivariate central limit theorem to the average vector defined in equation (25) and whose expected value is provided by Proposition 2:

$$
\sqrt{\frac{n}{M}}\left(\binom{\tilde{V}_{3}(n, L)}{\tilde{V}_{3}(n, M-1)}-\binom{V(L \tau)}{V((M-1) \tau)}\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}_{2}\left(0, \Sigma^{Y}\right)
$$

Then, we apply the delta method in the same way as in the general case and we have:

$$
\sqrt{\frac{n}{M}}\left(\widehat{S_{1,3}^{2}}(n, L, M-1)-S^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \frac{\gamma_{1,3}(L, M-1)}{M}\right)
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\underline{\gamma_{1,3}(L, M-1)} & =\frac{4}{(M-1-L)^{2}}\binom{M-1}{-L}^{T} \Sigma^{Y}\binom{M-1}{-L} \\
& =\left\{\frac{(M-1)^{2}}{m}\left(K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}\right)+L^{2}\left(K((M-1) \tau,(M-1) \tau)-V((M-1) \tau)^{2}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-2(M-1) L\left(K(L \tau, L \tau)-V(L \tau)^{2}-2 \frac{m-1}{m} S^{2} V(L \tau)+\frac{3 m-4}{m} \frac{S^{4}}{4}\right)\right\} \frac{4}{(M-1-L)^{2}} \\
& =\frac{1}{M} \Gamma(L, M-1)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we used equations (26), (27), and (28). This proves the last result of the theorem.

# C. 2 Proof of Proposition 4 

Proof. Like in the proof of Proposition 2, the result on the first moment is immediate.
Regarding the second moment, we start with the case $v=2$. Following equation (22) together with Proposition 3, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{2}(n, L)^{2}\right]= & \frac{1}{k_{2}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k_{2}(n, L)-1}\left\{V(L \tau)^{2}+2(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}+2(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}+S^{4} / 4\right. \\
& \left.+2 \sum_{j=i+1}^{k_{2}(n, L)-1}\left(V(L \tau)^{2}+2 c(i-j+1)^{2}(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}\right)-2 c(0)(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}\right\} \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{2(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}+2\left(1-c(0)\right)(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}+S^{4} / 4}{k_{2}(n, L)} \\
& +\frac{4(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}}{k_{2}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k_{2}(n, L)-2} c(-i)^{2}\left(k_{2}(n, L)-1-i\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In addition, we can bound the following positive quantity

$$
\frac{1}{k^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k-2} c(-i)^{2}(k-1-i) \leq \frac{1}{k} \sum_{i=0}^{k-2} c(-i)^{2}
$$

which, noting that $c(-k)=\mathcal{O}\left(k^{2 H-2}\right)$ when $k \rightarrow \infty$ [25, Lemma 1], is $\mathcal{O}\left(k^{4 H-3} / k\right)=o(1 / k)$ if $H<3 / 4, \mathcal{O}\left(\log (k) / k\right)$ if $H=3 / 4$, and $\mathcal{O}\left(k^{4 H-4}\right)$ if $H>3 / 4$. This leads to the result displayed in Proposition 4 for $v=2$.

For $v=3$, using equation (21), we only have to modify the values at which the function $c$ is considered, compared to the case $v=2$, in particular, $c(0)$ disappears because increments are strictly disjoint:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{3}(n, L)^{2}\right]= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{2(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}+2(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}+S^{4} / 4}{k_{3}(n, L)} \\
& +\frac{4(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}}{k_{3}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{i=0}^{k_{3}(n, L)-2} c\left(-i-\frac{i+1}{L}\right)^{2}\left(k_{3}(n, L)-1-i\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting that $|c(-i-(i+1) / L)|<|c(-i)|$ for $i \geq 0$, we can use the same bound as in the case $v=2$ and we thus obtain the result displayed in Proposition 4.

For $v=1$, since $K(u, \delta)$ is not a constant in $\delta$ when $\delta \leq 0$, we have to modify the decomposition of equation (23) to make a distinction between non-overlapping increments: we thus incorporate

$2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L-l\right.$ pairs of increments of the type $\left(p_{u \tau}-p_{0}, p_{2 u \tau+l \tau}-p_{u \tau+l \tau}\right)$, with $l \geq 0$. Therefore

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)^{2}\right]= & \frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\left(k_{1}(n, L) K(L \tau, L \tau)+2 \sum_{l=1}^{L-1}\left(k_{1}(n, L)-l\right) K(L \tau,(L-l) \tau)\right. \\
& \left.+2 \sum_{l=0}^{k_{1}(n, L)-L}\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L-l\right) K(L \tau,-l \tau)\right) \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{2(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}+2(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}+S^{4}\left(4-\left(1-L / k_{1}(n, L)\right) 2 c(0)(L \tau)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}\right.}{k_{1}(n, L)} \\
& +\frac{4(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}} \sum_{1-L}^{k_{1}(n, L)-L}\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L-l\right) c(-l)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

We can write the same argument as in the cases $v \in\{2,3\}$ to bound the sum of the $c(-l)^{2}$ and finally, when $H \in(0,3 / 4)$, we can write

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)\right]=\frac{2(L \tau)^{4 H} \sigma^{4}-\left(2 L \tau\right)^{2 H} \sigma^{2} S^{2}+S^{4} / 4}{k_{1}(n, L)}+o\left(\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)}\right)
$$

thus leading to Proposition 4.

# C. 3 Proof of Theorem 2 

Proof. The absence of bias in the case where $H$ is known is a direct consequence of Proposition 4 and of the fact that, according to equation (8), $S^{2}=2\left(L^{\prime 2 H} V(L \tau)-L^{2 H} V\left(L^{\prime} \tau\right)\right) /\left(L^{\prime 2 H}-L^{2 H}\right)$.

We prove the consistency of $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, H\right)$ and $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, \widehat{H}_{L^{\prime \prime}}\right)$ for $v \in\{1,2,3\}$ in the same way as we did for Theorem 1: following Proposition 4, $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$ converges in probability toward $V(L \tau)$ because its asymptotic quadratic risk is zero; then, the continuous mapping theorem concludes.
Regarding the convergence in distribution of $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, H\right)$ or $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, \widehat{H}_{L^{\prime \prime}}\right)$, we first establish it for $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$. Like in the proof of Theorem 1, and noting $\Delta$ the operator transforming the process in an increment of duration $L \tau$, the variables $\left(\Delta \eta_{i \tau}\right)_{i}$ form an $\alpha$-mixing sequence, with $\alpha_{n}=0$ for $n$ sufficiently large, because of Assumption 3. The sequence $\left(\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}\right)_{i}$, also has an $\alpha$-mixing property, which can be proved in this Gaussian case by the equivalent maximal correlation mixing, with an $\alpha$ dominated by the correlation [50, Theorem 2]. The variables $\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}$ and $\Delta \eta_{i \tau}$ being independent to each other (Assumption 1) and mixing, $\left(\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}, \Delta \eta_{i \tau}\right)_{i}$ and thus $\left(\left(\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}+\Delta \eta_{i \tau}\right)^{2}\right)_{i}$ are mixing sequences with a parameter $\alpha$ lower than the sum of the $\alpha$ of each of the two components [20, Theorem 5.1]. In other words, since $\alpha_{n}=0$ for $\Delta \eta_{i \tau}$ and $n$ sufficiently large, the mixing condition of $\left(\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}+\Delta \eta_{i \tau}\right)^{2}$ is the same as the one of $\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}$ or of $\left(\Delta p_{i \tau}^{*}\right)^{2}$. As a consequence, a central limit theorem holds for $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$, whatever $v$, exactly in the same conditions as if the $\eta_{i \tau}$ were replaced by 0 , that is as soon as $H<3 / 4$ [25, Proposition 1]. This asymptotic property on $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$ also holds for vectors corresponding to various lags, such as $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime \prime}\right), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, 2 L^{\prime \prime}\right), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, 4 L^{\prime \prime}\right)\right)^{T}[25$, Proposition 3$]$.

Finally, we conclude about the convergence in distribution of $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, H\right)$ and $\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, \widehat{H}_{L^{\prime \prime}}\right)$ using the delta method. In particular, when $H$ is known, the framework is very similar to the one developed in the proof of Theorem 1, except that we consider the function $g:(x, y) \mapsto$ $2\left(L^{\prime 2 H} x-L^{2 H} y\right) /\left(L^{\prime 2 H}-L^{2 H}\right)$, whose gradient is

$$
\nabla g(x, y)=\frac{2}{L^{\prime 2 H}-L^{2 H}}\binom{L^{\prime 2 H}}{-L^{2 H}}
$$

Finally, we get

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\widehat{S_{2, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, H\right)-S^{2}\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}\left(0, \gamma_{2, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}, H\right)\right)
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\gamma_{2, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}, H\right)= & \frac{4}{\left(L^{\prime 2} \pi-L^{2} \pi\right)^{2}}\left[L^{\prime 4 H} \zeta_{v}(L) \sigma_{2, v}^{2}(L)+L^{4 H} \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) \sigma_{2, v}^{2}\left(L^{\prime}\right)\right. \\
& \left.-2\left(L L^{\prime}\right)^{2 H} \sqrt{\zeta_{v}(L) \zeta_{v}\left(L^{\prime}\right)} \sigma_{2, v}(L) \sigma_{2, v}\left(L^{\prime}\right) r_{2, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case where $H$ is unknown, we focus on $\left(L, L^{\prime}, L^{\prime \prime}\right)=(1,2,1)$. Let $h(x, y, z)=\log _{2}((z-y) /(y-$ $x))$. In equation (10), we have added an absolute value, which will not be required asymptotically for the delta method, because the limit of $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 4 L)-\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2 L)\right) /\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2 L)-\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)\right)$ is strictly positive. We first remark that $x^{\log y}=y^{\log x}$, so that $2^{h(x, y, z)}=(z-y) /(y-x)$. The delta method will be applied to the mapping

$$
\begin{aligned}
g(x, y, z) & =2\left(2^{h(x, y, z)} x-1^{h(x, y, z)} y\right) /\left(2^{h(x, y, z)}-1^{h(x, y, z)}\right) \\
& =2\left(z x-y^{2}\right) /(z-2 y+x)
\end{aligned}
$$

whose gradient is

$$
\nabla g(x, y, z)=\frac{2}{(z-2 y+x)^{2}}\left(\begin{array}{c}
(z-y)^{2} \\
2 y(y-z-x)+2 z x \\
(x-y)^{2}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and to the vector $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 1), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 4)\right)^{T}$, which is such that

$$
\sqrt{n}\left(\left(\begin{array}{c}
\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 1) \\
\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2) \\
\widehat{V}_{v}(n, 4)
\end{array}\right)-\left(\begin{array}{c}
V(\tau) \\
V(2 \tau) \\
V(4 \tau)
\end{array}\right)\right) \xrightarrow{d} \mathcal{N}_{3}(0, \Sigma)
$$

where $\mathcal{N}_{3}$ is the trivariate Gaussian distribution. The delta method directly leads to equation (11).

# D Proofs for the market model with autocorrelated trades
## D. 1 Proof of Proposition 5

Proof. The solution of equation (13) is

$$
\eta_{t}^{*}=\frac{\Xi}{\sqrt{2 \theta}} e^{-\theta t} W_{e^{2 \theta t}}
$$

Noting that $\mathbb{E}\left[\widetilde{\eta}_{t}\right]=0$ and $\operatorname{Var}\left[\widetilde{\eta}_{t}\right]=S^{2}$, the autocorrelation of the discrete-valued process is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{corr}\left(\widetilde{\eta}_{s}, \widetilde{\eta}_{t}\right) & =\mathbb{E}\left[\operatorname{sgn}\left(\eta_{s}^{*} \eta_{t}^{*}\right)\right] \\
& =\mathbb{P}\left(W_{e^{2 \theta t}} W_{e^{2 \theta s}}>0\right)-\mathbb{P}\left(W_{e^{2 \theta t}} W_{e^{2 \theta s}}<0\right) \\
& =1-2 \mathbb{P}\left(W_{e^{2 \theta t}} W_{e^{2 \theta s}}<0\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

by complementarity. For $x>0$ and $0<u<v$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(W_{u} W_{v}<0 \mid W_{u}=x\right) & =\mathbb{P}\left(\frac{W_{u}-W_{u}}{\sqrt{v-u}}<\frac{-x}{\sqrt{v-u}} \mid W_{u}=x\right) \\
& =N\left(\frac{-x}{\sqrt{v-u}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $N$ is the standard Gaussian cdf. Now, if $x<0$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(W_{u} W_{v}<0 \mid W_{u}=x\right) & =\mathbb{P}\left(\left.\frac{W_{u}-W_{u}}{\sqrt{v-u}}>\frac{-x}{\sqrt{v-u}} \right\rvert\, W_{u}=x\right) \\
& =N\left(\frac{x}{\sqrt{v-u}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By the law of total probability, we can thus write the following, noting $\alpha=((v / u)-1)^{-1 / 2}, g_{u}$ the Gaussian pdf of variance $u$, and applying a change of variable $y=-x / \sqrt{u}$ in the first integral and $y=x / \sqrt{u}$ in the second:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{P}\left(W_{u} W_{v}<0\right) & =\int_{-\infty}^{0} N(\alpha x / \sqrt{u}) g_{u}(x) d x+\int_{0}^{+\infty} N(-\alpha x / \sqrt{u}) g_{u}(x) d x \\
& =2 \int_{0}^{+\infty} N(-\alpha y) g_{1}(y) d y \\
& =\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{\pi} \arctan (-\alpha)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we prove the last line with Lemma 1 in [36]. Using equation (30) and replacing $u$ and $v$ by $e^{2 \theta s}$ and $e^{2 \theta t}$, we thus conclude that

$$
\operatorname{corr}\left(\tilde{\eta}_{s}, \tilde{\eta}_{t}\right)=\frac{2}{\pi} \arctan \left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{e^{2 \theta(t-s)}-1}}\right)
$$

# D. 2 Proof of Proposition 6 

Proof. Like in the proof of Propositions 1 and $3, K(u, \delta) 16 / S^{4}$ is equal to the quantity $\mathcal{K}^{+}$when $\delta>0$ or $\mathcal{K}^{-}$when $\delta \leq 0$, as displayed in Lemma 2, with parameters adapted to Assumption 4: $\sigma_{G}^{2}=\frac{4 \pi a^{2}}{S^{2}}$ and correlations depending on $\delta$.
When $\delta \in(0, u]$, we have overlapping increments and $\rho_{G}=\delta / u, \rho_{2,1}=\rho_{4,3}=e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}, \rho_{3,1}=$ $\rho_{4,2}=e^{-u / \lambda}, \rho_{3,2}=e^{-\delta / \lambda}$, and $\rho_{4,1}=e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}$. In this case, the relevant cokurtosis in Lemma 2 is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{K}^{+} & =\left(1+2 \frac{\delta^{2}}{u^{2}}\right) \sigma_{G}^{4}+4 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(1-e^{-u / \lambda}\right) \\
& +4\left(1-2 e^{-u / \lambda}+e^{-2(u-\delta) / \lambda}\right)+4 \frac{\delta}{u} \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(2 e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-\delta / \lambda}-e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

and we finally get

$$
\begin{aligned}
K(u, \delta)= & \left(1+2 \frac{\delta^{2}}{u^{2}}\right) u^{2} \sigma^{4}+u \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(1-e^{-u / \lambda}\right) \\
& +\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(1-2 e^{-u / \lambda}+e^{-2(u-\delta) / \lambda}\right)+\delta \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(2 e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-\delta / \lambda}-e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}\right) \\
= & V(u)^{2}+2 \delta^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(e^{-2(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-2 u / \lambda}\right)+\delta \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(2 e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-\delta / \lambda}-e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

In the case of non-overlapping increments, that is for $\delta \leq 0$, we have $\rho_{G}=0, \rho_{2,1}=\rho_{4,3}=$ $e^{-u / \lambda}, \rho_{3,1}=\rho_{4,2}=e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}, \rho_{3,2}=e^{\delta / \lambda}$, and $\rho_{4,1}=e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}$. In this case, the relevant cokurtosis in Lemma 2 is $\mathcal{K}^{-}=\sigma_{G}^{4}+4 \sigma_{G}^{2}\left(1-e^{-u / \lambda}\right)+4\left(1-e^{-u / \lambda}\right)^{2}$, which more simply writes $\left(\sigma_{G}^{2}+2\left(1-e^{-u / \lambda}\right)\right)^{2}$. We thus get $K(u, \delta)=V(u)^{2}$.

## D. 3 Proof of Proposition 7

Proof. Like in the proof of Propositions 2 and 4, the result on the first moment is immediate.
For $v=3$ and $v=2$, using respectively equation (21) and equation (22), along with Proposition 6, the terms $K(L \tau,(i-j+1) L \tau)$ or $K(L \tau,(i-j+(i-j+1)) L \tau)$ being all equal to $K(L \tau, 0)$, we get

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\widetilde{V}_{v}(n, L)\right]=\frac{2 \delta^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(e^{-2(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-2 u / \lambda}\right)+\delta \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(2 e^{-(u-\delta) / \lambda}-e^{-\delta / \lambda}-e^{-(2 u-\delta) / \lambda}\right)}{k_{c}(n, L)}
$$

with $u=\delta=L \tau$, thus leading to

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)\right]=\frac{2 L^{2} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(1-e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\right)+2 L \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(1-e^{-L \tau / \lambda}\right)}{k_{v}(n, L)}
$$

For $v=1$, since $K(u, \delta)=K(u, 0)$ for $\delta \leq 0$, we can use the same decomposition as in equation (23):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)^{2}\right]= & \frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\left(k_{1}(n, L) K(L \tau, L \tau)+\sum_{m=1}^{L-1} 2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L+m\right) K(L \tau, m \tau)\right. \\
& +\left(k_{1}(n, L)^{2}-k_{1}(n, L)-\sum_{l=1}^{L-1} 2\left(k_{1}(n, L)-l\right)\right) K(L \tau, 0)) \\
= & V(L \tau)^{2}+\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\left(k_{1}(n, L)\left(2 L^{2} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(1-e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\right)+2 L \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(1-e^{-L \tau / \lambda}\right)\right)\right. \\
& +2 \sum_{m=1}^{L-1}\left(k_{1}(n, L)-L+m\right)\left[2 m^{2} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4} e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\left(e^{2 m \tau / \lambda}-1\right)\right. \\
& \left.\left.+m \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(2 e^{-(L-m) \tau / \lambda}-e^{-\widehat{m} \tau / \lambda}-e^{-(2 L-m) \tau / \lambda}\right)\right]\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Subtracting $V(L \tau)^{2}$ and noting that $\sum_{m=1}^{L-1} e^{x m}=f_{L}(x)$ and $\sum_{m=1}^{L-1} m e^{x m}=f_{L}^{\prime}(x)$, we get the variance of $\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\widehat{V}_{1}(n, L)\right]= & \frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)}\left(2 L^{2} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(1-e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\right)+2 L \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(1-e^{-L \tau / \lambda}\right)\right. \\
& +4 \tau^{2} \sigma^{4} \sum_{m=1}^{L-1} m^{2}+\frac{S^{4}}{2} e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda} \sum_{m=1}^{L-1}\left(e^{2 m \tau / \lambda}-1\right) \\
& \left.+2 \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2} \sum_{m=1}^{L-1} m\left(2 e^{-(L-m) \tau / \lambda}-e^{-m \tau / \lambda}-e^{-(2 L-m) \tau / \lambda}\right)\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\right) \\
= & \frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)}\left(2 L^{2} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}+\frac{S^{4}}{4}\left(1-e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\right)+2 L \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(1-e^{-L \tau / \lambda}\right)\right. \\
& +\frac{2}{3} \tau^{2} \sigma^{4}(L-1) L(2 L-1)+\frac{S^{4}}{2} e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda}\left(f_{L}\left(\frac{S \tau}{\lambda}\right)-L+1\right) \\
& \left.+2 \tau \sigma^{2} S^{2}\left(2 e^{-L \tau / \lambda} f_{L}^{\prime}\left(\frac{\tau}{\lambda}\right)-f_{L}^{\prime}\left(-\frac{\tau}{\lambda}\right)-e^{-2 L \tau / \lambda} f_{L}^{\prime}\left(\frac{\tau}{\lambda}\right)\right)\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{k_{1}(n, L)^{2}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Noting that $k_{1}(n, L)=n-L$, we get the expected result.

# D. 4 Proof of Theorem 3 

Proof. The absence of bias in the case where $\lambda$ is known is a direct consequence of Proposition 7 and of equation (14).

We prove the consistency of $\widehat{S_{3, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, \rho\right)$ and $\widehat{S_{3, v}^{2}}\left(n, L, L^{\prime}, \widehat{\left(\rho^{L^{\prime \prime}}\right)^{1 / L^{\prime \prime}}}\right)$ for $v \in\{1,2,3\}$ in the same way as we did for Theorem 1: following Proposition 7, $\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L)$ converges in probability toward $V(L \tau)$ because its asymptotic quadratic risk is zero; then, the continuous mapping theorem concludes.
Regarding the convergence in distribution, since the sequence of observed prices is $\alpha$-mixing, with $\alpha_{n}$ exponentially decaying, we can apply the central limit theorem [18, Theorem 27.4], with an expression similar to equation (24) for the vector $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)\right)^{T}$. Our estimator of $S^{2}$, in the case where $\rho$ is known, is obtained with a function

$$
g:(x, y) \mapsto \frac{2\left(L^{\prime} x-L y\right)}{L^{\prime}\left(1-\rho^{L}\right)-L\left(1-\rho^{L^{\prime}}\right)}
$$

applied to $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}\left(n, L^{\prime}\right)\right)$. This function $g$ is the same as the one introduced in the proof of Theorem 1, up to the factor $\left(L^{\prime}-L\right) /\left(L^{\prime}\left(1-\rho^{L}\right)-L\left(1-\rho^{L^{\prime}}\right)\right)$. Therefore, obtaining $\gamma_{3, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}, \rho\right)$ from the expression of $\gamma_{1, v}\left(L, L^{\prime}\right)$ is straightforward. This proves equation (18).

When $\rho>0$ is unknown, we can write, for $n$ large enough, the estimator of equation (17) as $\widehat{S_{2, e}^{2}}(n, L)=h\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2 L), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 4 L)\right)$, where $h$ is defined in equation (20) and omit the absolute values introduced in equation (17). Once again, starting from the multivariate central limit theorem of the vector $\left(\widehat{V}_{v}(n, L), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 2 L), \widehat{V}_{v}(n, 4 L)\right)^{T}$, as in equation (29), we can apply the delta method for the function $h$, leading to the result displayed in Theorem 3.

abstract:
Starting from a basic model in which the dynamic of the transaction prices is
a geometric Brownian motion disrupted by a microstructure white noise,
corresponding to the random alternation of bids and asks, we propose
moment-based estimators along with their statistical properties. We then make
the model more realistic by considering serial dependence: we assume a
geometric fractional Brownian motion for the price, then an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck
process for the microstructure noise. In these two cases of serial dependence,
we propose again consistent and asymptotically normal estimators. All our
estimators are compared on simulated data with existing approaches, such as
Roll, Corwin-Schultz, Abdi-Ranaldo, or Ardia-Guidotti-Kroencke estimators.
